_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Radford Army Ammunition Plant (RFAAP) is a government-owned, contractor-operated facility located in Radford, Virginia. RFAAP is owned by the U.S. Department of the Army, and is currently operated under contract by BAE Systems, Ordnance Systems Inc. effective 1 July 2012. RFAAP has been in continuous operation since 1941. RFAAP maintains an accidental release prevention program that covers design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, management of change, and employee training associated with the facility's processes. RFAAP maintains 24/7 on-site security and fire services, and coordinates with the Montgomery County Local Emergency Response Committee to provide additional emergency response expertise if needed.

Regulated Substances at RFAAP



The primary operations at RFAAP are propellant manufacturing processes for both military and commercial purposes. The RFAAP primary activity is described as Explosives Manufacturing (NAICS Code 32592). As the Ammonia Oxidation Process (AOP) is not active at the current time, none of RFAAP's processes are considered to be listed under NAICs Code for Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing (325188). In support of these operations, RFAAP maintains more than the threshold planning quantity of four regulated substances:  nitric acid (CAS No. 7697-37-2), ethyl ether (60-29-7), ammonia (7664-41-7) and oleum (8014-95-7). Therefore, RFAAP is subject to the requirements of the RMP Rule (40 CFR Part 68).

RMP Covered Processes at RFAAP



The 2015 RMP revision is the first five-year major update since BAE Systems, OSI became the operating contractor of RFAAP.  As such, the approach that was taken during this update cycle was to perform a full revalidation of all processes at RFAAP, resulting in a redefinition of many of the covered processes previously described in the facility's RMP. 

 

The RMP covered processes at RFAAP as of the October 2015 update are summ

arized as follows:

?? Ethyl ether in combined storage and manufacturing processes (inclusive of Solvent Recovery, Activated Carbon Recovery System and all associated storage). Despite the geographical areas covered by these processes, these components are considered one single process of interconnected piping and vessels.

?? Ethyl ether in Transient Railcar Storage. Not previously considered by the former operating contractor.

?? Nitric Acid in storage at the Nitrocellulose Area and Acid Area, and all associated piping inclusive of transfer lines from the NAC/SAC. Formerly divided into two processes by the former operating contractor, but should be considered one single RMP-covered process of interconnected piping and vessels.

?? Oleum in storage at the Nitrocellulose Area and Acid Area, and all associated transfer piping. Formerly divided into two processes by the former operating contractor, but should be considered one single RMP-covered process of interconnected piping and vessels.

?? Nitric Acid and Oleum in Transient Railcar Storage. Not previously considered by the former operating contractor.

?? Ammonia in Bulk Tanks at the Acid Area and Associated Piping to the Nitrocellulose Area. 



Additionally, a proposed new ammonia process consisting of a satellite ammonia tank at the SCR unit in the Nitrocellulose Area was reviewed as part of the RMP for RFAAP's planning purposes. However, this process is still under design, and will be included in a later RMP update to EPA prior to its commissioning and after a full Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been performed. A major change since 2010 RMP update is that the AOP is not currently being operated. An RMP update would be conducted along with a new PHA prior to this process returning to operability, if this should occur.



Five-Year Accident History



The five-year accident history was evaluated for this 2015 RMP update. RFAAP's operating contractor changed effective 1 July 2012.  Based on the fact that an

RMP revision was not conducted between the last submittal in 2010 and 1 July 2012, it is assumed that no qualifying events occurred in this time period as they would have necessitated an update. The updated RMP document summarizes and evaluates all release events associated with each covered process, regardless of severity (i.e., inclusive of minor leaks contained entirely within secondary containment and with no personnel exposure). 

One accidental release event was identified which is required to be included in the five-year accident history for the oleum process. A spill occurred on 1 July 2012 resulting in a release of 137,000 lbs of oleum; a tank failed due to water infiltration via a fume-line, resulting in an exothermic reaction in the tank and its eventual catastrophic failure. On-site consequences consisted of property damage to several adjacent tanks at the tank farm and its associated secondary containment dike, as well as requiring railroad track repairs and soil remediation. Personnel injury requiring treatment other than first aid also occurred to employees responding to the spill. Offsite impacts were limited to a Virginia Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (VPDES) water permit deviation for pH at a monitored outfall; however, no damage to receptors occurred as a result (i.e., fish kills or vegetation impacts).

Off-Site Consequences Analysis - Worst Case

As required by the RMP rule, Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for Off-Site Consequences Analysis were developed.  Per EPA's guidance, the intention of these scenarios is to provide a basis for a discussion among the regulated community, emergency responders, and the public, rather than a basis for any specific actions. Of the covered processes modeled for RFAAP, two processes were addressed as flammable substance scenarios (ethyl ether), three were addressed as toxic liquids stored at ambient conditions (oleum and nitric acid), and one was modeled as a toxic gas stored under pressur

e (anhydrous ammonia). 



Due to the size of the RFAAP facility (i.e., a distance of 0.8 mi is required to cause impacts to public receptors at the Army Staff Village), Worst-Case scenarios were evaluated for all covered processes: only six of these processes are included in the RMP submitted to RMP*eSubmit, as the seventh is in the proposed stage and was evaluated internally for planning purposes. RFAAP followed EPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance in developing the Worst-Case release scenarios, and verified the results via RMP*Comp against the results obtained from the Guidance Reference Tables and Equations.  As required by the guidance, the worst-case release scenarios were modeled using the worst meteorological conditions, which are a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and an atmospheric stability class of F. The temperature of released substance was considered to be the highest daily maximum temperature for the three year look-back period was 95 degrees F which was measured on 30 June 2012. The following paragraphs describe the results of the modeling for the worst-case scenario.

Worst Case for Ether Processes: The worst-case release scenario associated with the ethyl ether process group was modeled as a vapor cloud explosion from one of the ether bulk storage tanks containing 296,662 lbs, which is the largest individual vessel in the process. As this is a flammable substance, it is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapor, which finds an ignition source, with 10 percent of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud detonation. The endpoint distance resulting from this scenario is 0.5 mi to 1 psi overpressure, which is contained entirely within the facility fenceline and does not result in impacts to the nearest public receptor. Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 1.



Worst Case for Ether Railcar Storage: The worst-case release scenario associated with the ethyl ether transient railcar storage was modeled as a va

por cloud explosion of a single railcar containing 178,626 lbs. As this is a flammable substance, it is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapor, which finds an ignition source, with 10 percent of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud detonation. The endpoint distance resulting from this scenario is 0.4 mi to 1 psi overpressure, which is contained entirely within the facility fenceline and does not result in impacts to the nearest public receptor.  Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 1.



Worst Case for Nitric Acid Storage and Transfer Piping: The worst-case release scenario associated with nitric acid in storage and piping assumes that the volume of the largest storage tank at the Acid Area Tank Farm (653,064 lbs) is immediately released into secondary containment. The release rate is based on the rate of evaporation from the resulting pool within the dike. The worst case release modeling indicated an endpoint distance of 2.5 miles and impacts to a population of 2,339. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). There are no environmental receptors identified for this release. Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 3.



Worst Case for Oleum Storage and Transfer Piping: The worst-case release scenario associated with oleum in storage and piping assumes that the volume of the largest storage tank at the Acid Area Tank Farm (827,560 lbs) is immediately released into secondary containment. The release rate is based on the rate of evaporation from the resulting pool within the dike. The worst case release modeling indicated an endpoint distance of 3.6 miles and impacts to a population of 6,057. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). The Jefferson Natio

nal Forest was identified as a potential environmental receptor for this release. The endpoint distance of 3.6 miles calculated for the 2015 RMP is substantively higher than described in previous RMP versions (0.6 miles) due to the application of temperature correction factors for the spilled liquid as required by the guidance. Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 3.



Worst Case for Nitric Acid and Oleum Transient Railcar Storage: The worst-case release scenario associated with nitic acid and oleum in transient railcar storage and piping assumes that the volume of the an entire tanker car (189,000 lbs oleum, 185,000 lbs nitric acid) is instantaneously lost to ground and a uniform pool of one centimeter depth is immediately formed. This is the required assumption for the worst-case modeling for this scenario, as the tanker cars are not stored within a secondary containment or impoundment. It is for this reason that although the total volume of the release is larger for the bulk storage tanks of nitric acid and oleum, the endpoint distances are larger for a railcar release since the surface area of the pool is not constrained by a dike.  For a strong nitric acid railcar, the worst case release modeling indicated an endpoint distance of 16.0 miles and impacts to a population of 140,714.  An oleum railcar worst case release would result in an endpoint distance of 12.0 mils and impacts to a population of 78,660. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). The Jefferson National Forest was identified as a potential environmental receptor for this release. Although the oleum process did have a qualifying event in its 5-Year Accident History (1 July 2012 spill), this process would have been classified as a Program Level 3 regardless, based upon the off-site consequences analysis and the fact that it is subject to OSHA Process Safe

ty Management (PSM).



Worst Case for Anhydrous Ammonia in Storage and Transfer Piping: The worst-case release scenario associated with anhydrous ammonia in storage and piping assumes that the volume of a single storage tank at the Acid Area (170,000 lbs) is immediately released into secondary containment. The release rate is based on the rate of evaporation from the resulting pool within the dike. The worst case release modeling indicated an endpoint distance of 4.4 miles and impacts to a population of 9,602. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). There are no environmental receptors identified for this release. Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 3.



Off-Site Consequences Analysis - Alternate Release



EPA requires that per 40 CFR 68.165(a), "the owner or operator of Program 2 and 3 processes shall also submit information on one alternative release scenario for each regulated toxic substance held above the threshold and one alternative release scenario to represent all regulated flammable substances held above the threshold quantity." Unlike the worst-case scenario which is explicitly prescribed by the EPA, the alternative release scenario is intended to be representative of the types of releases which may be encountered at the facility, or which possibly have already been encountered. No alternative release scenarios were considered for flammable substances, as all covered processes for ether were determined to be Program Level 1. Per the EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis, "alternative scenarios are not required for Program 1 processes." Based on the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.28(a), the minimum alternate release scenario requirements for RFAAP are one scenario each for: (1) ammonia, (2) SNA, and (3) oleum. 

Unlike the worst-case scenario which prescribes consideration

of the instantaneous release of the maximum quantity from the largest pipeline or vessel in a process, the alternative release quantity is based on the specific scenario. Therefore, development of the overall quantity as derived from the release rate and duration of release are dependent on the specifics of the alternative release scenario selected. Each individual alternative release scenario was evaluated to determine what level of mitigation is considered credible and appropriate based on the specifics of the each scenario. RFAAP considered multiple potential scenarios for each regulated substance, and subjected them to sensitivity analysis for emergency response planning purposes.  To facilitate this exercise, RFAAP utilized RMP*Comp for the modeling, in consultation with the guidance presented in EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis. All modeling was performed under meteorological conditions considering a wind speed of 3 meters per second and an atmospheric stability class of D. 



The alternate release scenario developed for ammonia assumes that a hole has developed in the liquid space of a storage tank at the Acid Area, via either flange failure or pipe shearing at the 18" line at the bottom of the tank. Additionally, pipe or flange failure was considered appropriate for this analysis due to being more credible for use in disaster planning purposes for the facility and less duplicative than modeling a tank failure which was already considered under the worst-case analysis. Administrative controls prevent filling of the ammonia tanks to greater than 50% of capacity, which is equivalent to a liquid height of approximately 65 inches above the flange location, based on the strapping table for this tank. Based on sensitivity analysis, a flange or weld leak of 15% of the total area was selected as a representative scenario, and is considered plausible. As sensitivity analysis indicated that this scenario is completely insensitive

to the duration used in the modeling, a duration of 10 minutes was selected. Only active mitigation is considered for this scenario based on the activation of the Halo water curtain system within the tank location. An effectiveness of 50% for the Halo system was assumed. Even though this tank is located with secondary containment, credit is not taken for passive mitigation in this scenario due to the assumption that the dike would be overfilled with the deluge water. The release modeling for the selected alternate scenario for ammonia indicated an endpoint distance of 1.2 miles based on RMP*Comp. The size of the population impacted by this release is estimated at 2,619, and potential public receptors include residential areas and recreational areas (New River). No environmental receptors are associated with this scenario.



The alternate release scenario developed for oleum was based upon the characteristics of the 1 July 2012 spill that was included in the process's 5-year accident history. This is consistent with 40 CFR 68.28(e) which requires that facilities consider their five-year accident histories and previous incidents as documented in the Process Hazards Analyses for their covered processes when selecting an alternate release scenario. The modeling scenario considered that the oleum tank at the Nitrocellulose Area tank farm developed a hole at the 60-in mark on the tank, with a liquid height of 30-in above this point. The size of the hole was considered as 2 sq in, which is consistent with personnel reports at the time that the leak was discovered. A liquid temperature of 300 degrees C was used in the model, based upon personnel observations that water sprayed on the tank in an attempt to reduce its temperature resulting in it flashing to steam. An estimated release quantity of 137,000 lb was modeled, and mitigation via the secondary containment dike is considered. The release modeling for the selected alternate scenario for ammonia indicated an endpoint

distance of 3.5 miles based on RMP*Comp, and the size of the population impacted by this release is estimated at 5,663. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). The Jefferson National Forest was identified as a potential environmental receptor for this release.



The alternate release scenario developed for nitric acid assumes that a failure occurs at the 3" transfer line between the Acid and the Nitrocellulose Areas. The scenario involved the complete failure of the line due to either shearing (e.g., external impact) or flange failure.  The release was considered as unmitigated due to the lack of a secondary containment dike at the location where the failure was assumed to occur, such as one of the open fields that this line crosses. The typical operational flowrate of this line during transfer is approximately 100 gallons/min; a range of volume loss was explored in the sensitivity analysis as described in the following section, and was selected at 80% for the purpose of modeling. This is considered plausible as a result of either flange leak or damage to the pipe support. Acid transfers occur at night, the remote areas where the transfer line crosses are unattended, and a partial loss of the transfer volume would not be likely observed by the operators until the transfer was complete. Therefore, release durations ranging up to 60 minutes were considered via sensitivity analysis, which is the average time-to-completion for a nitric acid transfer between the Nitrocellulose and Acid Areas; an event duration of 45 minutes was selected for this scenario. The release modeling for the selected alternate scenario for ammonia indicated an endpoint distance of 1.7 miles based on RMP*Comp, and a population impacted by this release is estimated at 3,710. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potentia

l public receptors include residential areas and recreational areas (New River). No environmental receptors are identified for this release.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



The following sections summarize the components of RFAAP's Accidental Release Prevention Program, as required under 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to RMP Program Level 3 processes, a number of processes at the facility are also subject to the OSHA process safety management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119. Therefore, RFAAP's Accidental Release Prevention Program is tailored to assure compliance under both the RMP and PSM regulations. 

Process Safety Information: RFAAP maintains records of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all covered processes.



Process Hazard Analysis: RFAAP's Plant Protection Standard 1.05 - Process Hazard Analysis details RFAAP's requirements for conducting both initial and updated PHAs in a manner compliant with 29 CFR Part ??1910.119(e). All critical safety actions prompted by PHA recommendations are required to be completed prior to process startup, and non-critical items are required to be completed within the timeframe established by the PHA. The required PHA revalidation frequency is specified as at least every five years after completion of the initial PHA to ensure consistency with the as-built design. All covered process PHAs were initiated within 5-years of the previous 2010 PHAs, but the final report dates were not available at time of RMP submittal to EPA in October 2015.



Operating Procedures: All operating procedures are available to all employees through the Document Control System, and the operators are routinely retrained on these procedures. Consistent with the requirements of 40 CFR Part ??68.69(a)(1), the process operating procedures contain steps for each operating phase, inclusive of initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdow

n, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown. RFAAP's operating procedures also include information on the operating limits of each process, inclusive of the consequences of deviation from these limits and the steps required to correct or avoid deviation. Procedures are subjected to a regular review and recertification to assure that the contained information is correct and up-to-date.



Training: RFAAP has a dedicated Training Department which holds the primary responsibility for conducting personnel training and also serves as the central repository for the maintenance of training records for all plant personnel. Each employee involved in the operation of any process at RFAAP is trained on the applicable Operating Procedures. All training includes emphasis of the specific safety and health hazards associated with the equipment and chemicals involved, as well as emergency operation and safe work practices. Initial training for each operator consists of reading the procedure, and being instructed firsthand on process operations via a walkthrough with the procedure in-hand. Upon any procedure change, each operator is retrained using the same methods as for initial training. The Training Department maintains a database of each employee's required training, including the date of the initial training, the date of the most recent training, and the date that the next refresher training is required.



Mechanical Integrity: RFAAP has established written procedures to ensure the ongoing integrity of process equipment and that employees are trained in conducing these maintenance activities. Additionally, the facility has an overarching Maintenance Plan which documents the Preventative Maintenance and Inspection System. The aspects of this plan satisfy the requirements of 40 CFR ??68.73 for addressing the ongoing mechanical integrity of pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and device

s, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. The centralized planning and tracking system of the Preventative Maintenance (PM) system at RFAAP is Maximo, which is an asset management software platform used to track the frequency of PMs and the date that the PM is closed. In the event that a defect is observed during a PM and additional work is required, the defect is noted on the work order, the original PM is closed, and a "PM Defect" work order is issued to track the corrective action to completion.



Management of Change: The Plant Process Control Board (PPCB) is the core of the overall Management of Change framework at RFAAP, and governs both process and non-process changes, ensuring that the applicable requirements of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, EPA 40 CFR Part 68, International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 9001, ISO 14001, and Occupational Health & Safety Advisory Services (OHSAS) 18001 are met. RFAAP's Document Control System is the central repository of all written operating procedures, forms, and all other applicable controlled documents. This is a computer-based Management of Change (MOC) system that can be accessed through any plant computer with network access. In addition to providing a centralized source for accessing the current operating procedures and associated controlled documents, this system also tracks the review and approval process for the appropriate personnel prior to procedure change implementation.



Pre-startup Reviews: The Plant Process Control Board conducts pre-start up reviews before a process is allowed to operate. Prior to start-up of a process, a Production Readiness Review Checklist must be completed and reviewed. A minimum of five (5) management-level representatives such as from Safety, Environmental and Operations must be present at the pre-startup evaluation and must concur with the decision to start and provide their signature of approval. The associated checklist ensures that procedures are in place and adequat

e, a hazards review has been performed, and training has been completed prior to startup.



Incident Investigation: RFAAP's Plant Protection Standard 1.77 - Safety Incident Reporting & Investigation Requirements describes the reporting and investigation requirements for events involving explosions, motor vehicle incidents, severe storm or weather damage and spills with occupational injuries. Per this written procedure, the "investigation team must be formed and the investigation started as soon as possible based on the class of the incident and the conditions surrounding the incident and affected area." RFAAP's Management Manual 3-1.01 - Environmental Quality and Safety Incident Reporting additionally describes the process for incidents that are classified as environmental in nature and do not necessarily trigger the Safety incident requirements. All spills at RFAAP are required to be reported and investigated as Environmental events, even if the event is a nominal release entirely contained within secondary containment and without resulting in any health or safety impacts. Investigation of even minor events and near-misses is considered a means of identifying and addressing potential issues, and thereby preventing more significant events. The incident investigation report is reviewed with all affected personnel and all incident investigation reports are retained for a minimum of five years.



Employee Participation: The Employee Safety Committee is established at RFAAP to promote safety compliance at the Radford Army Ammunition Plant. Through this forum, employees are able to meet monthly to identify and discuss safety and health issues and propose recommendations to the management team. Employee involvement in incident investigations and Process Hazard Analyses is also required at RFAAP. Per Plant Protection Standard 1.77 - Safety Incident Reporting and Investigation Requirements, all incident investigation teams are required to include employees representing Op

erations, Maintenance, and Wage Employees as core team members. Plant Protection Standard 1.05 - Process Hazard Analysis describes RFAAP's requirements for employee participation, as representatives from multiple functional areas are required to be on the team.



Contractors: All contractors, subcontractors and tenants at RFAAP are required to read and certify by signature that they understand and will abide by the rules identified in the General Plant Rules for Contractors, Subcontractors, Tenants and Government Employees. Representatives from Safety, at a minimum, attend a Pre-Work meeting to ensure that this information is clearly communicated. The booklet includes information ranging from general safety procedures, such as ladder use and hot work, as well as facility-specific hazards.



Compliance Audits: RFAAP Environmental is responsible for initiating, conducting, and documenting the RMP Compliance Audits on a minimum of a 3-year cycle. Any identified deficiencies are documented in the associated report, and tracking-to-resolution of proposed corrective action will be documented through RFAAP's Environmental Event Report (EER) system.



Emergency Response Program



RFAAP has several plans and procedures which satisfy the emergency response requirements of 40 CFR Part ??68.95 and were developed to be protective of human health and the environment. The Disaster Control Plan describes procedures, event communication and personnel responsibilities in the event of a disaster, as RFAAP recognizes that the potential for a chemical release exists as secondary to a causative external event, such as a natural event or act of terrorism. RFAAP also maintains a RFAAP Fire Prevention Plan and Hazardous Material Response Plan.



Planned Safety Improvements



Several projects are in progress at RFAAP to improve safety in the RMP covered processes. A construction project to replace the legacy Solvent Recovery stills is ongoing with completion expected in 2016, and this

modernized facility will improve the safety of personnel working with ethyl ether in this plant area. A multi-year project to refurbish and improve the Acid Area Tank Farm, inclusive of strong nitric acid and oleum storage, is in progress and will involve improvements/replacements to the legacy tankage as well as to the secondary containment dikes. As described in this RMP, a project is underway to evaluate and design a satellite ammonia tank to be potentially sited at the SCR, which is the only current ammonia user on plant at this point in time; use of a smaller tank would mitigate risk of release.
